B000002AH1|4.0|I think the liner notes to Freddie Hubbard's album \\"First Light\\" express Miles Davis' situation in the early and mid-1970s the best: by entering the world of jazz-rock (fusion), Miles was simply living off reputation alone as the preferred jazz trumpeter.  Only a few years before, Miles scored hits with \\"In A Silent Way\\" and the landmark \\"Bitches Brew\\" - and it seemed, as if by doing so, Miles phenomenal jazz trumpet becomes ever so minimalistic and easily tired leaving others, like Freddie Hubbard, to gain the title of #1 jazz trumpeter in the early 70s.<br /><br />Not only was Miles living off of reputation alone, but this reputation seemingly allowed him to boast of friendships with Jimi Hendrix and Sly Stone, to exploit these friendships through creative measures, and allow his sidemen to take the forefront of his music while he, himself, settles back and offers the occasional off-key blast.  In fact, Miles' work on this album is quite unexceptional.  His solos, for the most part, are easily notated with quarter or eighth note trumpet blasts or squeals rather than actual full measures of solos.  If this album were any measure of Miles Davis's talent, then he'd be equated with the likes of William Hung, Pimp Daddy Welfare, and any novice attempting to play the trumpet.<br /><br />While this record clearly does not boast of Miles Davis' particular skills in any shape or format, it does possess some of the finest work by his sidemen: Keith Jarrett, Jack Dejohnette, Chick Corea, John McLaughlin, and Wayne Shorter, Herbie Hancock, and Ron Carter from his Second Great Quintet during the mid-1960s.  Because of the truly great level of playing by these men, this is some of the finest jazz-rock (fusion) I've ever heard.<br /><br />\\"Sivad\\" begins with a funky groove supplemented by keys, bass, and drums - and as it delves further into time, it melts into a casual conversation between each respective instrument.  \\"Little Church\\" reminds me of Close Encounter of the Third Kind with its ambient rhythmic support.  \\"Funky Tonk\\" lives up to its name, while \\"What I Say\\" is a 21 minute investigation into the world of drums, keys, and bass with Miles' occasional trumpet blast and an extended solo by Gary Bartz.  Each song is clearly enjoyable and sets the standard for jazz-rock (fusion) for many years to come.hird Kind with its ambient rhythmic support.  \\"Funky Tonk\\" lives up to its name, while \\"What I Say\\" is a 21 minute investigation into the world of drums, keys, and bass with Miles' occasional trumpet blast and an extended solo by Gary Bartz.  Each song is clearly enjoyable and sets the standard for jazz-rock (fusion) for many years to come. <br />
B000002UA5|3.0|The first of this two-disc set is comprised of rather raucous renditions of some of the Floyd's earliest material. The live versions at times outshine the studio versions, and listening to David Gilmour's guitar work on Astronomy Dominie in particular shows the listener why he was chosen to fill Syd Barret's shoes as a guitarist. Gilmour is unequaled, perhaps the most under rated player in popular music. Careful With That Axe, Eugene also betters it studio counterpart, the build-up is scary as all hell, and the screams near the end are chilling. Very gripping, and an indispensable document of their early years. Unfortunately the same cannot be said of the majority of the solo tracks that comprise disc two. The only song I have adopted into the Classic Floyd Cannon is Water's Grantchester Meadows. The vocal melody is brilliant, the words even more so. And the tender folk ballad ends with a delightful bit of found sound - a fly buzzes round the ears until it is chased and swatted. What remains of the solo material is either underdeveloped, self-indulgent or just plain unlistenable. It shows that  as a band they are an unparalleled musical  force, and as individuals they are marginally  creative, at best. Buy this one for the live tracks, if you are a fan of early period Pink Floyd, and skip over what you don't care for on the studio disc.

Most thinking people couldn't, wouldn't follow this Genghis Kang type of theology that preaches a dangerous intolerance that's known to less ignorant victims throughout the world. I'll bet you thought the Serbs just loved killing Bosnians for the joy of commiting murder, huh? No, they killed the Bosnians because they'd had it up to here with Islam's sick intolerance of other faiths, the illogical taxes on NOT being Islam, their ridiculous laws on how the others should DRESS, EAT and DRINK. Muslims in Serbian-dominated areas were left alone, why not Serbians in Muslim-dominated areas?<br /><br />Where Jesus taught his people to \\"Search the scriptures,\\" Islam expects only obediance and submission. And since Muhammad is supposed to be Allah's \\"last messenger,\\" spiritual guides are only that. With no revelation from Allah, no guiding spirit, many of Islam's self-appointed leaders go forth and command blood baths to the extent their followers are willing to carry them out. All by the authority of the Qur'an.<br /><br />The author also exposes the myths surrounding the crusades. Most casual students only see the top of the iceberg and rely on Islamic leaders to record how unjust the crusades were. I can't speak for the author, but I believe there will be room in hell for many people on both sides who shed innocent blood.<br /><br />In the meantime, I recommend this book only if you're unwilling to read a history of the Qur'an and the Qur'an itself. I don't know who conjured the words that the prophet recited, but it wasn't the God of Abraham. It wasn't the God who led Moses out of Egypt or said the greatest of all commandments was to love one's fellow man.<br /><br />To Muslims I recommend this book. I also recommend they look for the telltale signs of inspiration that would come from a book dictated and commissioned of God. I can find none. Reading it makes my heart stone that man would murder his fellow man with such casual disregard. \\"Allah assigns a person to participate in jihad...and nothing compels him to do so EXCEPT 1) belief in Allah...that he will be rewarded by Allah with a reward or booty, or 2)he will be admitted to Paradise [if he is martred].\\"<br /><br />Before I cut anyone's throat, I'd certainly find out who's holding the keys to the gates of Paradise and who dictated what to whom and under what circumstances. Making the wrong decision could land a soul in a world of hurt, and for a very long time.<br /><br />Finally, cultural differences abound between Islam and most other religions today. As the author notes, The Qur'an and Islamic law treat women as nothing more than the possessioh of men, the Qur'an sanctions wife beating and it allows for child marriages.<br /><br />Again, this isn't your kindly neighbors; Islam is a religion that thankfully is neglected by most of its adherents. What scares me is that the fundamentalist extremists seem to be smart enough to interpret the book correctly, but spiritually blind enough not to see who its author is.ms I recommend this book. 0345440927|3.0|Tracey Hogg shares her secrets for maintaining order in a house where a toddler resides in Secrets of the Baby Whisperer for Toddlers.  Those familiar with Ms. Hogg's first book, Secrets of the Baby Whisperer, know of her affinity for acronyms.  The acronym for this book is HELP.  She encourages parents to learn how to become HELPing parents, rather than \\"authoritative\\" or \\"enabling parents.\\"  She uses examples from real-life cases of how HELPing , authoritative, and enabling parents handle various situations with toddlers.  The goal is for readers to guage where they are on the continuum and correct behaviors that aren't HELPful.<br /><br />The most useful section of the book, for me, was the chapter on R&R (Rest and Rituals).  Ms. Hogg breaks down each event in the day (ie:  mealtimes, nap time, bath time, bedtime, etc.)  and explains what she says and what she does to prepare a toddler for each of these.  If a toddler is given consistancy in his or her daily roultine, then Ms. Hogg maintains, a lot of the battles commonly associated with toddlerhood will be thwarted.<br /><br />Other useful sections include how to get a toddler to sleep through the night, how to get a toddler to be less clingy, and how to prepare a toddler for the arrival of a new baby.<br /><br />Although I found this book to be more useful than her first, I still found some of Ms. Hogg's points debatable.  She still categorizes toddlers into five basic personality categories as she did in Secrets of the Baby Whisperer.  I was still unable to categorize my two children into these categories.  When I thought that I finally figured out the category of my child, I would read later in the book about how that child would typically handle a situation, and it didn't at all apply to my child.<br /><br />She also provides some unconventional advice about letting your toddler regard his/her crib as a place to play.  I had always heard that a child should see it as a place to sleep.<br /><br />I think that Secrets of the Baby Whisperer for Toddlers is worth reading.  At the very least, you'll get some ideas about how you can make life a little less chaotic (if it is that way in your house) through the use of rituals.  That in itself should make a household with a toddler more manageable.think that Secrets of the Baby Whisperer for Toddlers is worth reading.  At the very least, you'll get some ideas about how you can make life a little less chaotic (if it is that way in your house) through the use of rituals.  That in itself should make a household with a toddler more manageable.

The added bonus is that you can croon with Woolfson when you're not noodling the leads.

B000002KIE|3.0|I disagree with \\"Rock Snob\\" that considering this album as a work of art displays a lack of musical understanding or ability.  As a musician who has not only performed live for pay and recorded cds I'd like to think that I know something about music as well.<br /><br />The Sex Pistols and this album are very important in the whole history of rock and roll because of its influence on countless other bands and musicians to come such as Nirvana, The Clash, Green Day and other punk bands not to mention Heavy and Thrash Metal bands.  Although they by no means were the first and only to start the punk movement as many others could lay claim to this honour e.g. The Ramones, The Velvet Underground and even Blondie but the Sex Pistols did have talent but they just chose to play in a certain discordant style to put their message across but that doesn't mean the album isn't good or that they're not good musicians.  I thought the guitar solo on \\"God Save the Queen\\" was pretty good.<br /><br />You have to listen to the album for what it is and what it stands for and as an early representative of the punk rock genre, this is actually very good.  I'm just waiting for my remastered version to be shipped to me soon so that I can fully enjoy a little more closely what this classic must have sounded in the studio.  This was never meant to sound like pop or classical music anyways so how can you say this sucks unless you compare it to something else?  If you say compared to other albums in the genre, this sucks at least I can respect and understand your rationale but how can you possibly say that about a band and album that virtually created the whole frickin genre?<br /><br />Ironically, \\"Rock Snob's\\" reaction to the album is probably precisely what the Sex Pistols intended and were hoping for anyway.<br /><br />My recommendation: a must have for any serious music hobbist's collection but try and get the remastered version as the volume levels on this one are very low.  Peace!Peace!

0312935080|5.0|I've been reading Michael Connelly's Harry Bosch novels in order and they just keep getting better and better.  In this novel, we return to an incident referenced obliquely in the first two books: Harry Bosch's killing of Norman Church, a murderer known as \\"The Dollmaker.\\"  Bosch had violated police procedure by going to the Dollmaker's apartment alone, and had shot the Dollmaker after incorrectly concluding that he'd been reaching for a gun.  Nonetheless, the LAPD concluded that the Dollmaker had indeed committed eleven brutal murders.  Although makeup from nine of the victims was found in the Dollmaker's possession, Bosch now finds himself a defendant in a federal court civil trial brought by the Dollmaker's wife, where he is accused of having violated the Dollmaker's civil rights.<br /><br />The description of this trial, which weaves throughout the novel, is riveting.  Mrs. Church is represented by a high-profile attorney known for her legal skills and air of righteous indignation.  Bosch is represented by a Deputy City Attorney.  (This novel takes plenty of potshots at the Los Angeles City Attorney's office, with quotes like this: \\"These guys like Bulk, they couldn't make it on the outside .  .  .  If he had to win in order to eat, your lawyer would be a thin man.  He needs that steady paycheck from the city coming in, win or lose.\\")  Nonetheless, Bosch is hopeful that given the ample evidence against the Dollmaker, the jury will enter a defense verdict.<br /><br />But wait -- as the trial begins, another body turns up, murdered the very same way as the other victims.  Known as \\"The Concrete Blonde,\\" she was murdered after Bosch had killed the Dollmaker.  Could Bosch possibly have killed the wrong man?  Or is there a copycat killer about?  If so, can the police find him in time?  Will any of this affect the ongoing trial?  And what will the jury verdict be?<br /><br />This is truly a can't-put-it-down novel that has everything you want: an exciting detective story; a fascinating trial; well-drawn, multi-dimensional characters who defy stereotypes; and Michael Connelly's on-the-money description of the City of Los Angeles and the people who live here. It has just enough plot twists (but not too many) to make the ending completely unpredictable, but believable.  (This is an area where Connelly's previous novels suffered a bit.)<br /><br />While I enjoyed \\"The Black Echo\\" and felt that \\"The Black Ice\\" was an excellent read, \\"The Concrete Blonde\\" is by far the best of the lot. Five stars plus!etective story; a fascinating trial; well-drawn, multi-dimensional characters who defy stereotypes; and Michael Connelly's on-the-money description of the City of Los Angeles and the people who live here. It has just enough plot twists (but not too many) to make the ending completely unpredictable, but believable.  (This is an area where Connelly's previous novels suffered a bit.) <br /> <br />While I enjoyed \\"The Black Echo\\" and felt that \\"The Black Ice\\" was an excellent read, \\"The Concrete Blonde\\" is by far the best of the lot. Five stars plus! <br />

B0002858YS|5.0|A year ago I said that Keane were the biggest band of 2004 in Britain, and I was right. Now I'm saying, a year later, that the biggest band of 2005 in Britain is far and away The Killers. Coldplay have now gone global and Radiohead are still AWOL, leaving new acts to break into the industry. The Killers have succeeded perhaps more than any new act this year. Their debut album, \\"Hot Fuss,\\" was released in June 2004, but despite the hype, didn't really set the charts alight. That all changed in January 2005 when the band re-released one of the album's best songs and began their swift ascent up the charts. Hot Fuss is one of the biggest selling albums of the year shifting well over 1 million copies and propelling the band into the super-elite of multi-million selling acts.<br /><br />On the cover of my copy of Hot Fuss, the UK Independent newspaper is quoted as saying: \\"A classic debut, destined to become one of those unifying albums that everyone plays to death. Five stars.\\" It doesn't really get much better than that, or indeed, true. The album has spent the entire year in the Top 40 and shows no signs of budging! To begin with, I didn't take too well to The Killers. I was bored of the onslaught of new rock bands. You also couldn't escape this band in early 2005. They were everywhere, and I got majorly annoyed! However, over time something clicked and I gave in and bought the album. I haven't looked back. This is truly an amazing album.<br /><br />The album opens with \\"Jenny Was A Friend Of Mine.\\" This song opens with the sound of distant helicopters getting closer, as synths slide up and down and the driving guitar beat crashes in to land. This song just blows you away from the first minute, as a scene is set up in the first verse and explained through the proceeding choruses and verses. I love it where Brandon Flowers sings, \\"I swore I'd never let her go-o!\\" The next song is one of the best on the album. \\"Mr. Brightside\\" opens with a distant guitar and soon explodes into a rock anthem for a generation. This song has such a melancholy feel to it, which teenage boys around the world no doubt relate to immensely. \\"Smile Like You Mean It\\" was my favourite song for ages earlier this year. The synths in this song are incredible and so powerful. The arrangements of both vocals and instruments is so simple yet so effective. \\"Somebody Told Me\\" is the biggest and most famous song from the album by far. This song crashed into the UK Top 3 earlier this year and became played to death! That's one of the reasons I grew to dislike the band. However, maybe in a few month's time, I can listen to this song more frequently. Don't get me wrong, it's a stunning powerhouse of a track that races along on its driving bass beat like a galloping race horse! Overexposure is usually not very good, though, but one can't deny the brilliance of this song. I can see people pounding their fists in the air for years to come in clubs to this classic.<br /><br />\\"All These Things That I've Done\\" is a superb piece of music and acts as the centrepiece for the whole album, dividing it into halves. The intro this song is amazing and Flowers' classic chant of \\"I've got soul, but I'm not a soldier\\" is practically anthemic! And come on, who doesn't nod their head furiously when Brandon sings, \\"I need direction to perfection, no no no no?!\\" Maybe that's just me! \\"Andy, You're A Star\\" is a bit of a let down in that it isn't as up to the standard of the first five songs. Brandon sings about Andy, a guy at his school who he is clearly smitten with. The guitars are a bit 'off' for me, though. This one will please the gay fans, though, including me! \\"On Top\\" opens with spiky synths that dazzle and explode as the guitars and drums pound in. This is another brilliant song that deserves more attention, because Brandon's vocals are really stunning in the verses.<br /><br />\\"Glamorous Indie Rock & Roll\\" is another superb song that may take a while to grow on you, but once it does you'll be waving your arms in unison with all your mates. The chorus sways with beautiful rock simplicity, while the voice is just brilliant as usual, dominating the whole song. \\"Believe Me Natalie\\" has been called a filler track by many reviewers, but I definitely don't think so! Okay, this song might not be the strongest on the album but it's not weak. This is a very synth-orientated song, and more dreamy than anything else on the album. I love the way the verses are arranged, because they're very memorable and the synths simply melt your heart as they dance around like neon lights in a night sky. The final minute of the song puts more emphasis on those gorgeous synths, coming right after a funky trumpet section! \\"Midnight Show\\" is a bit of a let down and probably my least favourite song on the album. It just never really grew on me, I'm not sure why. The album closes with the beautiful \\"Everything Will Be Alright.\\" This song is very hazy and foggy, like a cloudy scene with vocals penetrating the mass. Brandon sings some beautiful lyrics here, and the chorus is very good too.<br /><br />OVERALL GRADE: 10/10<br /><br />I never thought I'd be giving this album a 10/10 but I really think it deserves it! Some people say this album isn't a classic. I beg to differ. I think in a few year's time, people will look back and remember this album as the sound of 2005. Brandon Flowers is a brilliant frontman and also incredibly sexy. I could look at pictures of him all day! Some say his voice is monotonous. I beg to differ. I think it's very distinct and unique. This review is quite late, of an album that was recorded well over a year ago, but better late than never! I can't wait for The Killers' second album. It will be huge, and I hope it's just as good as this brilliant debut.unison with all your mates. The chorus sways with beautiful rock simplicity, while the voice is just brilliant as usual, dominating the whole song. \\"Believe Me Natalie\\" has been called a filler track by many reviewers, but I definitely don't think so! Okay, this song might not be the strongest on the album but it's not weak. This is a very synth-orientated song, and more dreamy than anything else on the album. I love the way the verses are arranged, because they're very memorable and the synths simply melt your heart as they dance around like neon lights in a night sky. The final minute of the song puts more emphasis on those gorgeous synths, coming right after a funky trumpet section! \\"Midnight Show\\" is a bit of a let down and probably my least favourite song on the album. It just never really grew on me, I'm not sure why. The album closes with the beautiful \\"Everything Will Be Alright.\\" This song is very hazy and foggy, like a cloudy scene with vocals penetrating the mass. Brandon sings some beautiful lyrics here, and the chorus is very good too.    OVERALL GRADE: 10/10    I never thought I'd be giving this album a 10/10 but I really think it deserves it! Some people say this album isn't a classic. I beg to differ. I think in a few year's time, people will look back and remember this album as the sound of 2005. Brandon Flowers is a brilliant frontman and also incredibly sexy. I could look at pictures of him all day! Some say his voice is monotonous. I beg to differ. I think it's very distinct and unique. This review is quite late, of an album that was recorded well over a year ago, but better late than never! I can't wait for The Killers' second album. It will be huge, and I hope it's just as good as this brilliant debut.

B000056MOQ|5.0|Musically this DVD is of superb quality. Von Karajan's conducting is - as usual - fantastic; the vocals are strong and without the shrill whine that passes for singing in too many performances these days (why do modern composers feel the need to use choirs composed mainly of squeaky voiced pre teens); the Orchestra is in great form; and the photography is very well done. Catholics will probably have no problem in following the Mass and relating it to the music, but people unfamiliar with the Catholic Eucharist will find themselves lost at time. The written notes on the performance are useless and I suggest that sacred music specialists will find reading Nel's article on Mozart's Coronation Mass much more useful.

This album is softer, sweeter, and quieter.  There is more attention to detail, and less is focused on the noise factor.  The reviewer below me must have not heard their old albums, because this is their most quiet piece of music to date.<br /><br />This is the kind of music you listen to before photographing your children building their first snowman, or you riding the bus on a foggy morning in a rural town to school.  It's an appreciation for the little things, and this comes through in the music as you grow to see that each note is of equal importance to the ones before it.<br /><br />While ( ) and AB before it led is into a dramatic world of Icelandic culture searching for beauty in their simple way of life, Takk shows us the exactly how to get there, and how beautiful it can be.  The sheer subtle beauty within every Icelandic whisper can penetrate even the most jaded of ears.<br /><br />I cannot recommend it higher.  In my 2005 top 5.

B000AL730O|4.0|Paul McCartney proves again that he can make a quality CD if he puts his mind to it and works with a collaborator who can provide creative tension and honest feedback.  I'd give this well-crafted CD 4.5 stars.  It is worth repeated listening and has legs; it should grow on people who have eclectic tastes in music and listen to it without preconceived expectations.  Don't purchase this CD expecting big Wings-like hits or rockers.  Although most of the songs may not be as great as McCartney's best Beatles, Wings, and solo gems, many are quite good, and a number of songs would have fit comfortably with late-period Beatles (imagine if the Beatles had done them!): Promise to You Girl, Fine Line, Jenny Wren, Friends to Go, English Tea.  The well has not yet run dry! <br /> <br />I generally don't purchase music because of the quality of the lyrics (it's frosting for me, so I'm not going to comment on the lyrics), and I don't have high expectations of McCartney's lyrics, though he is capable of a good lyric if he sets his mind to it.  That said, it is refreshing that there is more emotional counterpoint and depth in this album and somewhat darker tonal shadings than the typical McCartney album.  People should expect that McCartney is never going be Dylan or Costello. <br /> <br />Here are my brief comments about each song. <br /> <br />Fine Line.   <br />Catchy verse.  Like McCartney's Beatles songs, this song effortlessly segues between verse, bridge, and chrous.  Shadings of the propulsiveness of Lady Madonna with a dash of I Am the Walrus strings. <br /> <br />How Kind of You <br />Although the melody could be better and although the melody and arrangement are not well-matched in my opinion, especially at the beginning, sonically and texturally, this song covers interesting ground and bears a closer listen. <br /> <br />Jenny Wren <br />McCartney is a master at writing simple intimate acoustic melancholy melodies that effortlessly shift from major to minor keys and back.  I love this kind of music.  It has a nice melody, and it stylistically evokes Blackbird.  The Rocky Raccoon-like ending undercuts the mood somewhat though. <br /> <br />At the Mercy <br />The opening of this well- produced song is unexpected and takes getting used to, a staircase of flats in a minor key.  But as it shifts back and forth from minor to major keys, it gets more interesting, and the song grows on you.  Worth a closer listen. <br /> <br />Friends to Go <br />Friendly, comforting Traveling Wilsbury-esque song evokes the spirit of George Harrison. <br /> <br />English Tea <br />This ditty echoes Martha My Dear but not quite as catchy. <br /> <br />Too Much Rain <br />According to McCartney, a sideways rewrite of Smile.  A good song which moves around a bit and has its moments but doesn't quite jell as a whole for me. <br /> <br />A Certain Softness <br />A soft, slinky Latin-styled, lounge song with touch of jazziness-not for everyone, but pleasant to listen to.  Loved the piano counterpoint. <br /> <br />Riding to Vanity Fair <br />I didn't care much for this melody, but others might find it more interesting to listen to for the lyrics and atmosphere. <br />  <br />Follow Me <br />A pleasant slower tempo relative of Hope of Deliverance.  Sounds as if this song could have been produced by Jeff Lynne. <br /> <br />Promise to You Girl <br />My favorite song of the CD!  A jaunty piano-driven that also would have been a worthy complement to Lady Madonna.  The harmonic bridge recalls Bohemian Rhapsody.  I love the melody and tempo changes, the nice little guitar solo, and Wings-like period bridge. <br /> <br />This Never Happened Before <br />This beautiful \\"silly love song\\" captures the feeling of yearning and love as So Bad did-a new wedding standard?  When the verse segues expansively towards the bridge, a single note gushes with romanticism-wonderful! <br /> <br />Anyway <br />When it works, songs that have different melodic parts pieced together (e.g.,A Day in the Life, Good Vibrations, Suite Judy Blue Eyes, etc.) are special.  I think the different parts of this song would have worked better as separate songs.  Nevertheless, it is still a good song.  I especially enjoyed the quite-hummable cozy folk-country-like refrain. <br /> <br /> <br />Bonus Montage <br /> <br />Track One <br />Nice blusy jam. <br /> <br />Track Two <br />Shows that can write new-age music if he is inclined to.  Brings to mind Heather from Driving Rain. <br /> <br />Track Three <br />To me, the only throwaway, and it probably was.  Like listening to the traffic sounds crossed with electronic doodling.

B0009R1T7M|4.0|Ted Kooser, the poet laureate of America, writes in his book \\"The Poetry Home Repair Manual\\": \\"You'll never be able to make a living writing poems.\\"  Well, I have to agree with Mr. Kooser, as there simply isn't a great demand for poets or poems in the modern day USA.   <br /> <br />But, if one can put their poetry to music, then the sky's the limit.  Jim Morrison, Bob Dylan, Joan Baez, Simon and Garfunkel and many other's found a way to meld poetry and music; now those names and the wealth & fame they generated are legendary.   <br /> <br />Well, it looks like an almost completely unknown artist from Holland, Michigan might be in the running for the title of great American lyricist, and perhaps ten or twenty years from now, the name Sufjan Stevens will be held in the reverent awe that so many of us have for those who proceeded him.   <br /> <br />Sufjan's album \\"Illinois\\" is one of the most refreshing and beautiful albums to come out of the \\"pop/rock\\" category in the past five years.  Of course, if you've been listening to pop/rock these past five years, that ain't saying much.   The secret to this album's amazing sound is that Sufjan is a product of folk music and literature, a surprising and rare combination that we haven't seen in quite some time.  You can also hear a spattering of jazz here and there, especially in the piano, which other reviewers have pointed out reminds them of Vince Guaraldi, as it does myself. <br /> <br />But the sound of this album is definitely of the folk-rock genre (not really \\"pop/rock\\"),  a genre that's been all but dead for the past twenty years or so.  As I listen to Sufjan's \\"Illinois,\\" it brings me back to the late 60's and early 70's, to those wonderful sounds made by people like Cat Stevens, CSN&Y, America, Simon & Garfunkel, The Mamas and the Papas, Janis Joplin, and all the rest that helped bring folk-rock to the front and center of the music industry and American culture.  Sufjan's music is firmly rooted in these old vines, but it's not a rehash of 60's protest music.  There is a freshness, a newness to his sound that makes you believe that a new era is dawning.  Is he as good as the greats from the past?  No, not yet; but then that's a hard crowd to compete against. <br /> <br />Sufjan's breathless voice reminds me of Steve Miller for some odd reason, perhaps it's the mellow approach they both seem to have towards their music.  But the lyrics and the orchestration are way beyond anything I've heard in the past twenty years.  Again, one has to go way, way back in time to find something comparable.  Even more remarkable is the almost home-spun way this album was made: recording in basements, living rooms and churches.  No mega-fancy recording studio here, just very good musicians doing what they love.  <br /> <br />There are a few songs on this album that are real stand-outs, though many songs on the album deserves some sort of recognition.  <br /> <br />The first is \\"John Wayne Gacy,\\" a song about serial killer who raped and murdered thirty young men, then hid them under the floorboards of this home.  When I saw this title on the cover of the CD, I thought it would be some kind of joke, but instead I was caught completely off-guard.   Sufjan uses Gacy as a vehicle to remind us all that we aren't that much better than those we demonize, and goes forth and sings one of the most beautiful and haunting ballads about Gacy that I've ever heard anyone sing about a serial killer.  But this song isn't about some sort of morbid curiosity or goofy melancholy, but an honest examination of our own human condition. <br /> <br />Carl Sandburg made a name for himself with his poem entitled \\"Chicago,\\" Sufjan is poised to do likewise with his song \\"Chicago.\\"  A simple, folksy song that has little to do with the city it's named after, and a lot about making mistakes.  Fun lyrics and some cool orchestration make this tune almost pop-like, but not quite. <br /> <br />Right after \\"Chicago\\" is the curiously titled song \\"Casimir Paulaksi Day.\\"  Again I thought it would be some sort of joke about the Illinois legislature, but instead we have a simple folk ballad about the innocence of young love, and the tragedy of youth ended by cancer.  Sufjan carefully avoids delving into melancholy and remorse, but rather gives us a very powerful, beautiful song that easily flows into the realm of the spiritual.  It's my favorite song of the set.   <br /> <br />Don't do what I did when I first played this album: I had my player set on \\"random\\" and heard the songs out of their intended order.  Upon finding my error, I turned the randomizer off, and listened to the tracks in their proper order-what a difference!  There is a very deliberate and powerful logic to the order of the songs. <br /> <br />Laced into every note on this CD, especially the three songs I liked the best, is something you almost never hear in today's music: humility.  Sufjan is doing his best to tell us about his mistakes, his weaknesses, his struggles.  No ass-kickin' cowboy here: just a guy trying to be honest about himself, and his humanity.    <br /> <br />Yet Illinois isn't the \\"perfect\\" album that so many make it out to be.  There are flaws, there are songs that shouldn't be on this CD.  It, like an overly long novel, needs a good editor.  Yet there is enough meat that one doesn't mind having to kick out an occasional bone or two.  As good as Illinois is, I think there are still better albums yet to come from the mind of Sufjan. <br /> <br />No, this CD isn't for everyone.   It won't \\"rock\\" enough for some young head-bangers, and that's OK.  But for those who appreciate a truly inspired, powerful, beautiful blend of music, there's not much better than \\"Illinois.\\"  <br />

B000A0GP4K|5.0|Dylan has always been an elusive subject. Myth and fact cloaking him well on his long journey, and it seems the more we know the more complex the man becomes. <br />In this 3 hour+ documentary Scorsese weaves a wonderful mixture of archival footage and interviews, with Dylan's insightful narrative, creating what is both an exploration of a career and a keen account of the 1960's music scene.  <br />No Direction Home helps explain the fascination with Dylan as visionary poet and prolific musician. <br />Scorsese manages to convey Dylan's impact on the folk/rock/country/blues scene illustrating how his mastery of tradition fueled and informed the progress of the genre. <br />It's a great in-depth look at a long and complicated career and it only covers up to 1966!! <br />And in the process of telling Bob's rich tale Scorsese reveals,  more than a little, of just how the 'star-maker machinery' turns a man into a myth.

B00005KB9R|4.0|Rather like the Beatles, Bob Marley's best album is whichever one you happen to be listening to. Burnin' was the second album Bob Marley made for Chris Blackwell's Island label (in conjunction with Tuff Gong), which, like the first, came out in 1973. It's a well named album as it is incendiary from start to finish with both he and Peter Tosh at their most revolutionary. They were at home playing much of the material as they had previously recorded several of the songs in versions produced in recent years by Lee Perry, so the performances were relaxed, assured and deadly, and several feature Peter Tosh and Bunny Wailer, who were both soon to strike out on their own.<br /><br />Two of the bonus tracks are unreleased out-takes but Reincarnated Souls had been the B-side of Concrete Jungle (lifted from Catch A Fire). 0393035158|4.0|Sam Harris's book is provocative and thoughtful, and therefore worth reading. However, I believe he misdiagnoses the problem of destructive faith as merely one of traditional religions. He is correct that certain writings and doctrines of traditional religions, if taken literally, and without regard for common moral intuitions, can lead to extreme anti-human actions. In an era where it is easy to get access to destructive weapons, this can be extremely dangerous to a decent world civilization. But the most destructive ideologies of the last 100 years have been those of Hitler, Stalin, and Mao. None of these ideologies is based on a belief in God. Harris briefly describes Stalinism and Maoism as constituting \\"a political religion\\" and claims that the Nazis were \\"agents of religion\\" (p. 79 of the book). This is using the term \\"religion\\" in an extremely loose sense as any unquestioning faith that crushes human beings in the service of ideology. Furthermore, I do not think that most religious believers in the world use religion in the way described in the book, although too many do. The real problem is broader than fanatical religion, and is the problem of human attraction to fanatical faiths of any kind.

B000AADYYO|3.0|Don't worry, I will explain my title! just read on!    ************    Hearing Ghost Reveries was an odd thing for me. I was somewhat skeptical about Opeth joining Roadrunner; I also wanted to hear the borderline black metal album that Mikael had promised on the Lamentations DVD because Opeth are at their best when they are at their heaviest. Instead, upon hearing the new album I got the following idea in my head:    Opeth should break up.    Ever since their three masterpieces Blackwater Park, Still Life and My Arms, Your Hearse their sound seems to have been stagnating. Deliverance was a decent album, but somewhat weakened by their attempts to push their songs past the 10 minute mark. Damnation was OK, but compare any of it to \\"Epilogue\\" from My Arms, Your Hearse or \\"Patterns in the Ivy\\" from Blackwater Park and it seems like a fairly mediocre exhibit of their softer work.    Then Ghost Reveries appeared. It, even more so than Deliverance, just sounds like Opeth going through the motions of making their sound. It lacks any of the power of their three masterpieces and since it is in basically the exact same style as those albums it is just worse on the whole. The biggest change in their sound since My Arms, Your Hearse has been the addition of more prominent keyboards on Ghost Reveries, but those go unnoticed at best, and sound awkward and out of place at worst. Everything else is pushing the boarders of Opeth's trademark sound without really improving on it or changing it in any way. For a \\"progressive\\" metal band Opeth do not seem to progress that much, even Dark Tranquillity or Soilwork have changed more over the course of their careers than Opeth have.     Besides the keys I only really noticed two other changes: Mikael experimenting more with his clean vocals and the changing of most of the heavy parts to almost wannabee Meshuggah chugging parts (see \\"The Grand Conjuration\\" for a prime example of this). Neither of these are good changes, since Mikael's experimentations are not very interesting and the \\"CHUG *pause* CHUG\\" style riffing is kind of boring. At the end of the album, you basically get 2 minutes of good, heavy Opeth on \\"Reverie/Harlequin Forest\\", 2 nice soft songs in the form of \\"Hours of Wealth\\" and \\"Isolation Years\\" and a somewhat interesting intro to \\"The Grand Conjuration\\" that quickly fades into a boring song after that.    It is sad to see one of the last great Swedish melodeath bands fall into mediocrity - with this album it basically leaves us with just Dark Tranquillity left holding the banner high - but that is what happened. I guess I will stick to enjoying the three masterpieces by these talented Swedes.

0446677450|1.0|At first reading this book will get the blood boiling of any person who is interested in getting rich. This book appeals to people looking for the 'quick fix' and not people willing to put in the time and the effort into their financial education.  This can be seen by the fact that Kiyosaki does not explain anything to do with finance but rather uses emotion to appeal to the reader.   <br /> <br />The book is particularly dangerous in the hands of teenagers and those at school.  Kiyosaki's dislike of the education system leads him to suggest that education (through traditional forms) is outdated and outmoded because of his bad experiences within the system.  The educational system which Kiyosaki scorns is the reason that some countries advance and other countries are left behind in the dust. <br /> <br />More dangerous than this book is the book Rich Dad's Guide to investing becuase, as well as oversimplifying sometimes complex financial processes, wrong information is often provided.  One example is in the explanation of the use of technical and fundamental investing.  Any first year finance student knows that these are in essence incompatible becuase on assumes that the market is ineffiecient and the other assumes that the market is efficient.  As it cannot be both, investors (and therefore authors) take one side or the other.  Kiyosaki however claims that the two can be combined with the right 'education'.  This sort of information can lead to ordinary people making rash decisions. <br /> <br />I must admit that i was a huge supporter of Robert Kiyosaki however since begining a finance degree im seeing how wrong many of his statements are <br /> <br />As a final note one of the other worries in this book is that Kiyosaki seems to equate happiness with having money and although i would love to be a millionare - there is something wrong with the concept that having a large amount of money would make you happy. <br /> <br />This book is good if you want to get excited and realise that you need to take control of your life however if you want answers to financial problems or to be set on the road to financial freedom other books which provide sound advice may be a better option
B000002P5W|4.0|There are several reviewers who believe that Axis: Bold As Love is the ULTIMATE Jimi Hendrix album. I would argue for Electric Ladyland. Actually, I think that Axis is Jimi's weakest album. It's still good, but has the most filler out of every Hendrix album. How about if we just scrap One Rainy Wish, She's So Fine and Ain't No Telling? Yeah, sounds like a plan to me. And Little Miss Lover isn't quite up to Hendrix's standards.<br /><br />However, this does have some of Jimi's finest moments. In my mind, Castles Made of Sand has the best damn lyrics ever to appear on a Hendrix tune, and that guy could write a song! He also pushed the fusion moment with If 6 Was 9, the Nonconformist's (i.e. people like me) National Anthem. Plus, there's a nice flute solo. And you'd be hard-pressed to find a more beautiful song than Little Wing. The title track is also great, as is Spanish Castle Magic, a metal-seeming track.<br /><br />Though it doesn't compare with Are You Experienced? or the earth-shattering Electric Ladyland, Axis is worthy of the Hendrix name. But watch for some of the weak moments.

B00003CXCW|5.0|Sunset Boulevard is a real classic I first learned about from parodies on The Carol Burnett Show in the 1970s.  I didn't see the film until some 20 years later, when I found it fascinating.  William Holden (Rachel And The Sranger, The Earthling) plays Joe Gillis, a bankrupt B-movie writer who drives his car into the garage of an apparently abandoned mansion on Sunset Boulevard to dodge the repo men.  But the dilapidated place is occupied by two fascinating but weird characters, former silent screen star Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) and her butler, balding, german-accented Max (Erich von Stroheim).  Norma hires Joe to ghost-write a screenplay for her come-back, but he soon finds he's as much a kept-man as a writer, enabling more than one of the has-been starlet's delusions.  The characters of both Norma and Max are fascinating enough to keep the movie going, and their relationship turns out to be more than it seems.  The cast includes a very young Jack Webb, actually speaking like a human being, and appearances by Buster Keaton, Hedda Hopper, and Cecil B. DeMille as themselves.  Carol Burnett made great fun of the role with Harvey Korman in the Max role 2 decades later, but the movie (directed and co-written by Billy Wilder) remains a grand drama, character study, and serious comment on the Hollywood star system.

I was the only girl mechanic at that time, and I remember very well waiting in line before the races with Dick Mann on one side of me and Jay Springsteen on the other...... this movie brings tears to my eyes every time I watch it. B0009S8H0I|5.0|Every now and then, a truly original, groundbreaking band surfaces amid all the bland pop and rock. Montreal's Arcade Fire is one such band. In their glorious full-length debut \\"Funeral,\\" Arcade Fire spins elaborate art-rock full of passion and atmosphere.<br /><br />Rather than trying to hook you the way most songs do, Arcade Fire builds up their songs to a musical (and emotional) crescendo. The album opens on a four-song cycle called \\"Neighborhood,\\" which deal with daydreams, neglect, fighting in a family, and just sitting around waiting for life to happen to you. All four things are pretty clearly considered disastrous -- don't waste time, make life happen!<br /><br />Certainly that get-off-your-bum-and-make-things-happen attitude carries over to the wild \\"Wake Up,\\" a howling anthem with an ever-evolving beat, and the well-named \\"Rebellion,\\" where Win sings, \\"\\"Sleeping is giving in/no matter what the time is/Sleeping is giving in/so lift those heavy eyelids.\\" You'll be emotionally exhausted when it reaches the wrenching finale, \\"In the Back Seat.\\" And it does all this while making you dance too. There are bonus tracks, including a vivid B-side and a live performance, which are the ones that stand up to the original work. The other two just don't quite gel.<br /><br />Most pop or rock songs are focused on \\"He/she left me/cheated on me and I'm miserable\\" or \\"I'm so in love.\\" Don't expect anything so obvious from the Arcade Fire. These are about living life in general, not just one part of it. Why's it called \\"Funeral\\"? Partly the fear of dying without having accomplished something.<br /><br />Musically, it will make your head spin. There's a blend of post-punk, rock, art-rock, pop, folk, classical, and much more -- like a punkier version of Neutral Milk Hotel or Modest Mouse. Woven together are xylophone, shimmering strings, swirling keyboard, piano, violins, and accordians. And they're all set to epic, crashing art-rock and disco rhythms.<br /><br />And Win Butler is about as laid-back as his music. He can belt out tormented vocals like few can, shout, wail, whimper, and just sing. And his wife Regine offers equally angsty backing vocals. Which is a good thing, because it takes good vocals to do justice to brilliant songwriting like \\"The neighbors can dance in the disco police lights.\\"<br /><br />The Arcade Fire's \\"Funeral\\" is certainly a contender for \\"Best of 2004.\\" At the very least, it's a polished and wrenching debut, and likely to get you off your butt and out living life. If joie de vivre had a sound, this is what it would sound like.ythms.    <br />    <br />And Win Butler is about as laid-back as his music. He can belt out tormented vocals like few can, shout, wail, whimper, and just sing. And his wife Regine offers equally angsty backing vocals. Which is a good thing, because it takes good vocals to do justice to brilliant songwriting like \\"The neighbors can dance in the disco police lights.\\"    <br />    <br />The Arcade Fire's \\"Funeral\\" is certainly a contender for \\"Best of 2004.\\" At the very least, it's a polished and wrenching debut, and likely to get you off your butt and out living life. If joie de vivre had a sound, this is what it would sound like.

It is forced to repay its debt to the US and other countries by buying weapons from the US and is not allowed to use any money that the US or other countries have given to Africa to establish schools, hospitals or any other critical, foundation infrastructure the country needs to bring it out of its depression.<br /><br />As far as the concert itself, it was simply stunning. B00006DEF9|5.0|Often considered the greatest movie musical ever made, Stanley Donen and Gene Kelly's SINGIN' IN THE RAIN (1952, MGM) starts with a witty Betty Comden and Adolph Green script about the advent of sound.  How did it revolutionize the film industry in the late 1920's and for actors who could not talk?  The plight of the latter is immortalized by Jean Hagen, in the performance of a lifetime as Lina Lamont, an actress with a loud and squeaky voice.  As someone says, \\"Lina's a triple threat-she can't sing, she can't dance, and she can't talk.\\" <br /> <br />The movie's three main stars are Gene Kelly as matinee actor Don Lockwood (and the movie's co-choreographer); Debbie Reynolds as Kathy Seldon, the pretty actress Don loves; and Donald O'Connor as best friend Cosmo Brown.  All three are wonderful, and Arthur Freed and Nacio Herb Brown give them fabulous songs to sing:  \\"You Were Meant For Me,\\" \\"All I Do is Dream of You,\\" O'Connor's show-stopping \\"Make `Em Laugh,\\" the title song, \\"You Are My Lucky Star\\", and the overwhelmingly colorful \\"Broadway Melody\\" climax. <br /> <br />The production values here are so colorful and irresistible-cinematography, production design, and costumes just don't get any more beautiful.  The movie is drenched in gorgeous color in every scene.  One could get drunk on this movie's visuals!  How, pray tell, they all three areas lose out on Oscar nomiations the year after AN AMERICAN IN PARIS (1951) swept the awards?  What was the Academy thinking?  Maybe one or two of them won for PARIS.  At least Adrienne Fazan DID get nominated for editing on SINGIN'.  Among the actors, only Hagen got nominated--and should have won the Oscar. <br /> <br />The version of SINGIN' IN THE RAIN that I am reviewing and that you should buy is the 50th anniverary double disk DVD from Warner Home Video.  Disk one has the movie shimmeringly remastered and with a lavish audio commentary by just about everyone still alive in 2002.  Disk two has two magnificent and informative documentaries, one on the Arthur Freed Unit at MGM and one hosted by Reynolds on the making of SINGIN'. Also on disk two are generous original movie excerpts from more than a dozen other MGM musicals that first used SINGIN' songs, and a deleted Debbie Reynolds song that someone had the brains to save in the vaults.  It is a glorious total set--under $25-- and worthy of this greatest of color musicals. <br /> <br /> <br />
0440180295|2.0|Kurt Vonnegut's Slaughterhouse 5 is seen as his best work and a modern classic although, having completed it, I'm left wondering why. Blending science fiction with his memoirs Vonnegut has created a meta-fictional novel where time travel is a primary plot device; one that allows him the freedom to dismiss chronology in the telling of his tale.<br /><br />Billy Pilgrim is a war veteran, having been a prisoner of war in a converted abattoir in Dresden. Years after the war he is involved in a plane crash which causes him to become \\"unstuck in time\\"; a strange condition that allows him to travel to any point in his life, or even to the planet Tralfamadore where the aliens that live there view life as a single representation of every moment. Through his frequent travels in time, Billy Pilgrim gets to relive many points of his life such as Dresden, his marriage, and even his death; all of these combine to show Billy's attempt at making sense of the world, his fatalist conclusions permeating the novel.<br /><br />The story of Billy Pilgrim doesn't start until the second chapter, the first, instead, being the author's apology for the novel's mess (although he states you can't make sense of a massacre) and how, in his mind, the book came to be. The prose is minimalist and repetitive. Phrases appear regularly or statements reappear reworded. The use of \\"so it goes\\" whenever something dies, be it a person or bubbles in champagne, is understandable, however, in its need to demonstrate death as something routine and cheap, it does become grating.<br /><br />There are many characters in Slaughterhouse 5 although I don't feel that any of them were given much depth. People appear for a paragraph and then Billy Pilgrim is off on his travels before you have a chance to get to know them. Even Billy failed to hold my attention, possibly because we fail to really get to know him. The author spends time telling us about him rather than showing him doing anything which, I feel, cheapens the experience. His condition, that of being \\"unstuck in time\\", leaves a nice ambiguity about the novel although it's highly probable that his travelling is a delusional passage between memories brought on by the trauma of witnessing the bombing of Dresden.<br /><br />Maybe the book is a product of its time or maybe there's something I'm missing but Slaughterhouse 5 is not a novel I'd recommend. Having no experience of Vonnegut's other work I can't say whether this book, being part memoir, is a typical example of his canon. While the novel is understandably a mess, I can't help but feel that the prose and characterisation are lacking and what, on paper, sounds like a great idea has been put through a literary slaughterhouse. So it goes.pens the experience. His condition, that of being \\"unstuck in time\\", leaves a nice ambiguity about the novel although it's highly probable that his travelling is a delusional passage between memories brought on by the trauma of witnessing the bombing of Dresden. <br /> <br />Maybe the book is a product of its time or maybe there's something I'm missing but Slaughterhouse 5 is not a novel I'd recommend. Having no experience of Vonnegut's other work I can't say whether this book, being part memoir, is a typical example of his canon. While the novel is understandably a mess, I can't help but feel that the prose and characterisation are lacking and what, on paper, sounds like a great idea has been put through a literary slaughterhouse. So it goes.

B000001G16|4.0|Fresh off their last two hugely successful albums, Slippery When Wet and New Jersey respectively, Bon Jovi decided to take a much deserved break in the early 1990's. Jon Bon Jovi released his first solo album, Blaze of Glory in 1990, while guitarist Richie Sambora, who co-wrote nearly all of the band's biggest hits, released his first solo album, Stranger In This Town, in 1991. Many times when a guitarist in a successful band, particularly one that plays hard rock, releases a solo album, the music presented is more based on the guitarist's six-string talents rather than the music. However, while there is more guitar here than on the Bon Jovi albums, Richie's solo debut is all about the songs. Stranger In This Town is a strong album containing both the anthems and power ballads that Bon Jovi made famous but also a couple ventures into the blues which are among the best tracks.<br /><br />The album opens with \\"Rest In Peace\\", which is essentially a 4-minute intro rather than an actual song. Consisting of keyboards and Richie's moody vocals and guitar work, it works very well despite its length. \\"Church Of Desire\\" is an awesome dramatic hard rocker with a great chorus that is one of the album's best tracks. \\"Stranger In This Town\\" is a killer blues complemented by both the glossy production and Richie's passionate vocals and solos. The album's single, \\"Ballad of Youth\\", is a great hard rocker with a memorable riff while \\"One Light Burning\\" is very melodic and laid-back. \\"Mr. Bluesman\\", another dramatic track that features both Richie and special guest Eric Clapton's tasty solos, is also an awesome track. \\"Rosie\\" and \\"River Of Love\\" are anthems that are decent but aren't as catchy as the ones Richie co-wrote with Jon Bon Jovi. \\"Father Time\\" is a bombastic power ballad that is similar to the ones that Bon Jovi made famous and is also very good. \\"The Answer\\" is a great acoustic tune that closes out the album. While not containing as many hooks and catchy songs as those on Slippery When Wet and New Jersey, Stranger In This Town is a strong album that shows Richie Sambora's exceptional talents as both a songwriter and a musician. Definitely worth picking up.ry When Wet and New Jersey, Stranger In This Town is a strong album that shows Richie Sambora's exceptional talents as both a songwriter and a musician. Definitely worth picking up.
B000001GQB|3.0|I can see someone admiring these recordings, since they are very well executed and crisply presented, with no major flaws. And I can see why Mozart was considered one of Karl Bohm's best composers if you like his foursquare, unsmiling approach. Apparently many other listeners and reviewers don't demand more than what this bargain set of the last six symphonies delivers.<br /><br />But Bohm's traditional Teutonic conducting sounds pretty limited to me, not because of the \\"authentic\\" movement now in vogue but because great Mozart conducting must be joyous, light on its feet, and full of wit and alertness. Bohm is brisk and efficient instead. Bruno Walter was born even earlier than Bohm, and yet he got all those things right.  That's why I return to him again and again, not to this set, much as I love the Berlin Phil.

0805079076|5.0|This is one of the most intellectually fascinating books I have ever read. As soon as I started thinking about the design of language, I have wondered how language comes about. Who decided which verbs would be regular and which irregular? Why \\"mice\\" instead of \\"mouses\\"? Even as a child, I wondered \\"Who decides these things?\\" (Admittedly, I was not a typical kid.) Why does our language change? Why is English spelling so goofy? How did the Latin noun case structure evolve? Who invented the Arabic triconsonantal pattern?     By now, many readers have said \\"Huh?\\" and moved on to the next book. But if these are things you've wondered about, this is the perfect book for you, too. Deutscher tries to explain the mysterious processes underlying the development and decay of languages. In his style of writing, he is walking a tightrope; this is a book that is aimed at intellectuals who are not knowledgeable about lingustics. At times he's a bit too cute for his own good, but I will forgive that flaw because it's preferable to being too obtuse. Deutscher's book will never make any bestseller list, but it has made the academic discipline of linguistics accessible to those outside his specialty.

B000ASATWQ|5.0|This album represents the new generation of youth that have been born into the rock the taino indians knew as xaymaca: a generation of youth raised on mtv, bet, the heavy riddims of the dancehall, the musical philosophies of rastafari, and cnn. As a child that was born into a priviledged upper-class family but with a father that well-knew and was personally involved in the ghetto realities so tied to politrics and the post-colonial, post-slavery world, damian marley is in a unique position. He has become to messenger between the haves and the have-nots, a messenger from the pain we feel as jamaicans and as citizens of this world to the listener of the first world. When the cry of \\"out in the streets they call it murder\\" sounds over the speakers, i am afraid something is lost in translation. This is not machismo or bravado. It is not something jamaicans are proud of that our murder rate tops colombia and south africa's. It is a small warning cry as to what hatred, division, and racism can do to a country, and by extention to the community known as mankind. This is Damien marley's message, a message of warning and of hope and of freedom in a dying world. This is not rap. You won't hear about car rims or designer clothes, and other such tangible, corruptible things. This album is illumination to bridge the spiritual and moral gap between what is happing in the post-colonial world and what will inevitably happen in the first. It is a moving story over a moving beat, tied in with the daily concerns of people everywhere. This record is jamaica. It represents what jamaica is in the 20th century in a way and with a beat that all can understand. It is the voice of the baby that is just now emerging from his mother's uterus, and it bawls to be heard.

630514415X|3.0|I love Denzel Washington. I mean, I absolutely adore this man...he never gives a less than credible performance in any role he plays. Once again, he delivers as a less-than-perfect father in \\"He Got Game\\". This is more than a story about basketball - it's about human relationships, the bond between a father and son, and how that prevails even in the worst of circumstances.<br /><br />The story, set in the Coney Island housing projects in Brooklyn, NY (where it was also filmed), surrounds Jake Shuttlesworth (Denzel) who has been imprisoned in Attica for the accidental murder of his wife. His son, Jesus (Ray Allen), a high school basketball star who is being hotly pursued to either go into college or sign with the NBA, has nothing but contempt and disgust for his father. If Jake can convince his estranged son to attend a certain university and sign a letter of intent, then his time will be reduced significantly, since this school also happens to be the governor's alma mater.<br /><br />It starts off with a lot of promise, when Jake is allowed out of prison for a week to try to talk to his son. But after a while, the plot starts to wear thin when Jake keeps approaching Jesus, and Jesus is always telling Jake to leave him alone. How long can this be stretched out before you get tired of the whole thing? Okay, you can throw in flashbacks of Jesus as a child and how his father pushed him hard to play ball; a scheming, opportunistic girlfriend (Rosario Dawson); money-hungry friends and relatives; and plenty of tempting offers to either take money, sign with the NBA, go to this college and so forth to thicken the plot. Everyone seems to want something from Jesus, and as a result he has very little trust for anyone around him, and understandably so. But even that tends to get monotonous because you keep hearing the same type of dialogue, only from different characters. But stay with it.<br /><br />This movie does show realistic situations that face talented high-school prospects that can play basketball, so Spike was on point with this. However, it is not the first film that touched upon this subject. There was also \\"Blue Chips\\" that had Shaquille O'Neal and Anfernee (Penny) Hardaway in it as students/basketball players being heavily recruited for colleges and how they were being paid off, depending on what their decision would be. (At the time this movie was out, both Shaq and Penny were members of the Orlando Magic.)<br /><br />Ray Allen is an NBA basketball player in real life, but he is NO ACTOR, just like Shaq and Penny aren't actors, either. Whatever scenes Allen appeared in were kind of painful to watch because the man just has no skills in that area. He does try, though. And the rest of the cast aren't much better, most notably Milla Jovovich. She plays a grimy and pathetic prostitute who is repeatedly abused by her pimp. I found it difficult to believe that Denzel or any man would find her to be desirable. But then again, Denzel as Jake was just coming out of prison, so...<br /><br />I also disliked the fact that Spike had to throw in so many sex scenes. I normally enjoy Spike's films, but why must he exploit women? He makes them look like they are nothing more than lowlife sexual playthings who are out to use men for what they have. \\"He Got Game\\" runs rampant with this, even casting porn star Heather Hunter in one of many (unnecessary) sex scenes! What the hell?! Although Spike does it on a smaller scale in his other movies, and always has, it didn't bother me as much as it did in this film. It was excessive. I understand the point that Spike was trying to make, but come on - couldn't he leave a little SOMETHING to the imagination?<br /><br />\\"He Got Game\\" is definitely worth watching. Not perfect, but not a waste of time, either. See it!etball, so Spike was on point with this. However, it is not the first film that touched upon this subject. There was also \\"Blue Chips\\" that had Shaquille O'Neal and Anfernee (Penny) Hardaway in it as students/basketball players being heavily recruited for colleges and how they were being paid off, depending on what their decision would be. (At the time this movie was out, both Shaq and Penny were members of the Orlando Magic.)    Ray Allen is an NBA basketball player in real life, but he is NO ACTOR, just like Shaq and Penny aren't actors, either. Whatever scenes Allen appeared in were kind of painful to watch because the man just has no skills in that area. He does try, though. And the rest of the cast aren't much better, most notably Milla Jovovich. She plays a grimy and pathetic prostitute who is repeatedly abused by her pimp. I found it difficult to believe that Denzel or any man would find her to be desirable. But then again, Denzel as Jake was just coming out of prison, so...    I also disliked the fact that Spike had to throw in so many sex scenes. I normally enjoy Spike's films, but why must he exploit women? He makes them look like they are nothing more than lowlife sexual playthings who are out to use men for what they have. \\"He Got Game\\" runs rampant with this, even casting porn star Heather Hunter in one of many (unnecessary) sex scenes! What the hell?! Although Spike does it on a smaller scale in his other movies, and always has, it didn't bother me as much as it did in this film. It was excessive. I understand the point that Spike was trying to make, but come on - couldn't he leave a little SOMETHING to the imagination?     \\"He Got Game\\" is definitely worth watching. Not perfect, but not a waste of time, either. See it!

0679446230|5.0|The genius of this novel is that, while the lens primarily focuses on the rise, fall, and recovery of its temperamental hero, the real plot surreptitiously sneaks up and doesn't really take hold until the end.  Achebe doesn't taint his story with his own judgments about people or what happens to them.  He just paints pictures of African tribal life- barns full of yams, the fragility of new life, the mystic but revered Oracle, folk tales that sound nonsensical to a Western sensibility.  Then he tells the story about how things fall apart in such a subtle way that you don't really think about it until you're done.  And you'll never forget.

B0002OERI0|5.0|I'll start off by saying that I am a conservative Republican and disagree with almost everything that Green Day says in their songs.  That being said, I think Green Day has released the most influential album to date.  For their seventh album released, it is unbelievably different from their other albums; they dared to make a change.  With this album they have completely abandoned the pop-punk genre that they created and have created an album that is by itself in a brand-new genre.  The lyrics are possibly the most innovative part of this album; don't ever criticize this album until you know the meanings behind all of these songs.  No band has ever made an entire story on an album like Green Day now has. The lyrics are so powerful and meaningful.  Here is a breakdown of each song.    American Idiot (3/5): Not the most original sounding song on the album, but it is necessary as it sets the tone for the entire album.  Jesus of Suburbia (5/5): I was blown away when I heard this five-part masterpiece.  The transitions to each individual part were so smooth they were almost unnoticeable.  Holiday (5/5): Currently my favorite song in the whole world.  The guitar and drums are amazing, not to mention the powerful lyrics.  Boulevard of Broken Dreams (5/5): Got me hooked on Green Day.  Feels like a second part to Holiday.  Once again, powerful lyrics + powerful music = a great song.  Has a potential to get old if you listen to it too much though.  Are We the Waiting (5/5): Cool drums, lyrics are kind of weird in the chorus, but awesome feeling with many people crying out: \\"Are We the Waiting?\\"  St. Jimmy (4/5): Musically, not the greatest, but the aggressive tone of the song is a great way to introduce St. Jimmy.  Give Me Novacaine (5/5): For some reason, it has a vintage feel to the verse, with an awesome chorus.  She's a Rebel (4/5): Good song, but starts to sound too much like old Green Day.  Extraordinary Girl (2/5): Worst song on the album.  Lyrics are repetitive of She's a Rebel and has a weird Indian intro. Gets points for attempting something musically different, though.  Letterbomb (4/5): Took a while for this song to grow on me, but its alright.  Wake Me Up When September Ends (5/5): This song knocks me off my feet. Unbelievably emotionally powerful lyrics about the death of Billie Joe's father, and yet it ties in perfectly with the American Idiot Storyline.  Homecoming (5/5): This also took a while to grow on me.  While not as good as JOS, it has its highlights with \\"The Death of St. Jimmy\\" and Mike Dirnt showing off his vocal skills in \\"Nobody Likes You\\".  Whatsername (5/5): What a way to close off the record! This song deserves a single. Lyrics leave you hanging, as well as the transition from soft, muted guitars to a powerful chorus with just a dropoff at the end.    This album is unbelievable.  To compare this to a Blink 182 album or a Good Charlotte album or even an older Green Day album is just plain ridiculous.  Beware that if you buy it, you may not be able to listen to anything else for a while. I've had it for over 6 months now, and thats still the case for me. Its that good.

B00005JNTX|4.0|To understand and appreciate this movie you'll need a little background information.  First of all, it's not one story, but a combination of three stories from the graphic novels of the same name, with a short clip from another story as an introduction.<br /><br />The introductory skit, starring Josh Hartnett and Marley Shelton, is from \\"The Customer is Always Right\\", the others being \\"The Hard Goodbye,\\" \\"The Big Fat Kill\\" and \\"That Yellow Bastard\\".<br /><br />Shot in a way that is as close to the original comics as possible, the movie is in black and white, except for certain highlighted objects in the frames that are vividly colored in stark contrast. B000BB1MI2|5.0|There is no doubt that Tim Burton has a penchant for things that are eccentric and sometimes plain creepy.  This isn't a bad thing, however -- as he demonstrates in CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY, being different can be fun and quite exciting.    For starters, the film has special effects and visuals that anyone would marvel at.  From the opening sequence onward, the viewer is awestruck at the Factory itself, the town below, and the sharp distinction made between these places and Charlie's little house.  The lighting is superb and the music is magnificent, making for a delectable opening sequence.  Grandpa Joe's storytelling then ensues with rich, vibrant colors and amazing scenery.    As the action continues and kids begin finding Wonka's Golden Tickets, we are introduced in turn to the winners (plus parents) and each of their peculiar quirks.  By the time the children end up in the Factory, we are formally introduced to Wonka himself -- a wonderfully odd, zany, and weird character in his own right (played beautifully by Depp).    The Factory tour consumes much of the rest of the film and accounts for a considerable amount of wackiness.  The verdant Candy Meadow, the River of Chocolate (plus the Waterfall!), and many other gorgeous locales await the viewer.  Each has its own peculiarities, but the adventure never stops as the group treks through the Factory, finding excitement and humor around every corner.    At the end of the day, this film radiates with Burton's creative talents.  I agree, however, that it is not for all ages.  Even some adults will be taken aback by the film's eccentricities, so letting really small kids watch it first might be reconsidered.  Keep in mind, however, that the wackiness is the only reason why this might be said -- the film is clean, fresh, and appropriate for children and adults (particularly the young at heart!).      My suggestion:  Let your mind go and relax as you take in the wild world of Willy Wonka.  And, if you have thechance, see this film in IMAX -- the true surround sound and size of the screen make it an unbelievable experience.  Very highly recommended.

B00004YA0T|5.0|The reason that this is the best complete symphony recordings of Bruckner is that conductor Eugene Jochum had a close relationship with Bruckner himself and knew the music like the palm of his hand. despite any negative commentary or the fact the preferred editions are conducted by the eminent Herbert Von Karajan, this box set is by far the best. All the symphonie sound great, polished, romantic, idealized, spiritual, energetic, passionate and mysterious, especially the opening movement of the final 9th, which comes in both versions here. This is a true winner for a recording box set. Your other choice should be Karajan though. But Jochum masters the music with great affinity and brilliant technical musicianship. In this recording, particularly impressive are the 7-9th. The early symphonies are German-Romantic Wagner/Mahler style but entirely Bruckner's individualized style. It is music that is heavy, and not music for a beginner to hear. It is deep, highly emotional, music to meditate by. It's slow-moving, dream-like and powerful, horns and brasses sounding fatalistic at times, while the winds and strings evoking either intensity or quietness. Bruckner himself would love this set. He certainly approved of Jochum conducting.
